chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Three rods made of same material and having same cross-section have been joined as shown in figure. Each rod is of same length. The left and right ends are kept at 0°C and 90°C respectively. The temperature of the junction of the three rods will be
question_latex: Three rods made of same material and having same cross-section have been joined as shown in figure. Each rod is of same length. The left and right ends are kept at $0^{\circ}C$ and $90^{\circ}C$ respectively. The temperature of the junction of the three rods will be
solution:
Let the temperature of junction be $\theta$. In equilibrium, rate of flow of heat through rod $1 = $ sum of rate of flow of heat through rods $2$ and $3$. 
 $(\frac{dQ}{dt})_{1} = (\frac{dQ}{dt})_{2} + (\frac{dQ}{dt})_{3}$ 
 $KA \frac{(\theta - 0)}{l} = KA \frac{(90^{\circ} - \theta)}{l} + KA \frac{(90^{\circ} - \theta)}{l}$ 
 $\theta = 2(90^{\circ} - \theta)$ 
 $3\theta = 180^{\circ} \Rightarrow \theta = 60^{\circ}$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: If the temperature of a hot body is increased by 50%, then the amount of radiation emitted by it are increased by nearly [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: If the temperature of a hot body is increased by $50\%$, then the amount of radiation emitted by it are increased by nearly [MHT-CET 2021]
solution:
Amount of radiation $E \propto T^{4}$. 
 $E_{1} = T^{4}$ 
 $E_{2} = (1.5T)^{4} = 5.0625 T^{4}$ 
 Increase in radiation $= \frac{E_{2} - E_{1}}{E_{1}} \times 100 = (5.0625 - 1) \times 100 = 406.25\%$. 
 (Note: The solution in the PDF implies $E_{2}/E_{1} = 1.5^{4} = 5.06$, increase $\approx 400\%$. Correcting to nearest option).

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The root mean square speed of the molecules of a gas is v. If the temperature of the gas is doubled and the gas at the same time dissociates into atoms, the new root mean square speed will be [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: The root mean square speed of the molecules of a gas is $v$. If the temperature of the gas is doubled and the gas at the same time dissociates into atoms, the new root mean square speed will be [MHT-CET 2022]
solution:
$v_{rms} = \sqrt{\frac{3RT}{M}}$. 
 When temperature is doubled, $T' = 2T$. When gas dissociates into atoms, $M' = M/2$. 
 $v' = \sqrt{\frac{3R(2T)}{M/2}} = \sqrt{4 \times \frac{3RT}{M}} = 2v$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The molar specific heat of an ideal gas at constant pressure and constant volume is Cp and Cv respectively. If R is universal gas constant and n is number of moles, then Cp - Cv is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: The molar specific heat of an ideal gas at constant pressure and constant volume is $C_{p}$ and $C_{v}$ respectively. If $R$ is universal gas constant and $n$ is number of moles, then $C_{p} - C_{v}$ is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: By Mayer's relation, for one mole of an ideal gas, $C_{p} - C_{v} = R$. Molar specific heat is independent of the number of moles used in the definition.

question_latex: The temperature of a black body is increased from $127^{\circ}C$ to $527^{\circ}C$. The ratio of the energies of radiation emitted will be [MHT-CET 2020]

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: A gas at pressure P0 is contained in a vessel. If the masses of all the molecules are halved and their speeds are doubled, the resulting pressure P will be [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: A gas at pressure $P_{0}$ is contained in a vessel. If the masses of all the molecules are halved and their speeds are doubled, the resulting pressure $P$ will be [MHT-CET 2024]
solution:
$P = \frac{1}{3} \frac{Nmv^{2}}{V} \Rightarrow P \propto mv^{2}$. 
 $P' \propto (m/2)(2v)^{2} = \frac{1}{2} m (4v^{2}) = 2mv^{2}$. 
 So $P = 2 P_{0}$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The emissivity of a perfectly black body is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: The emissivity of a perfectly black body is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: By definition, a perfectly black body has an emissivity ($e$) of $1$ as it emits maximum possible radiation at a given temperature.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: At what temperature will the root mean square speed of oxygen molecules be sufficient so that they escape from the earth? [Escape velocity = 11.2 km/s, Boltzman constant k = 1.38 x 10^-23 J/K, Mass of oxygen molecule = 5.34 x 10^-26 kg]
question_latex: At what temperature will the root mean square speed of oxygen molecules be sufficient so that they escape from the earth? [Escape velocity $= 11.2$ km/s, Boltzman constant $k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23}$ J/K, Mass of oxygen molecule $= 5.34 \times 10^{-26}$ kg]
solution:
$v_{rms} = \sqrt{\frac{3kT}{m}} = v_{esc} \Rightarrow T = \frac{m v_{esc}^{2}}{3k}$. 
 $T = \frac{5.34 \times 10^{-26} \times (11.2 \times 10^{3})^{2}}{3 \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23}} = \frac{5.34 \times 10^{-26} \times 125.44 \times 10^{6}}{4.14 \times 10^{-23}} \approx 1.6 \times 10^{5}~K$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The wavelength of maximum emission for a body at 2000 K is 1.5 micro-m. The wavelength of maximum emission for the same body at 3000 K will be [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: The wavelength of maximum emission for a body at $2000~K$ is $1.5~\mu m$. The wavelength of maximum emission for the same body at $3000~K$ will be [MHT-CET 2023]
solution:
From Wien's displacement law, $\lambda_{max} T = \text{constant} \Rightarrow \lambda_{1} T_{1} = \lambda_{2} T_{2}$. 
 $1.5 \times 2000 = \lambda_{2} \times 3000 \Rightarrow \lambda_{2} = \frac{3000}{3000} = 1.0~\mu m$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Which of the following is correct for an ideal gas? [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: Which of the following is correct for an ideal gas? [MHT-CET 2020]
options: D. Internal energy depends on volume
solution: For an ideal gas, there are no intermolecular forces, and consequently, the potential energy is zero. Internal energy depends only on temperature.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: A body is moved along a straight line by a machine delivering constant power. The distance moved by the body in time 't' is proportional to [2025, 2014]
question_latex: A body is moved along a straight line by a machine delivering constant power. The distance moved by the body in time '$t$' is proportional to [2025, 2014]
solution:
Power $P = Fv = m \frac{dv}{dt} v = \text{constant}$. 
 Integrating: $\frac{1}{2}v^{2} \propto t \Rightarrow v \propto t^{1/2}$. 
 Since $v = \frac{ds}{dt}$, $s = \int v dt \propto t^{3/2}$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Wien's constant b has the units of [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Wien's constant $b$ has the units of [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: From Wien's displacement law $\lambda_{max} T = b$. The unit is meter-Kelvin ($m \cdot K$).

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Two bodies A and B are projected with same velocity. If bodies A and B are projected at an angle of 30° and 60° with the horizontal respectively, the ratio of maximum height reached by the body A to that of body B is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: Two bodies A and B are projected with same velocity. If bodies A and B are projected at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ with the horizontal respectively, the ratio of maximum height reached by the body A to that of body B is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution:
$H_{max} = \frac{u^{2} \sin^{2} \theta}{2g} \Rightarrow H \propto \sin^{2} \theta$. 
 Ratio $= \frac{\sin^{2} 30^{\circ}}{\sin^{2} 60^{\circ}} = \frac{(1/2)^{2}}{(\sqrt{3}/2)^{2}} = \frac{1/4}{3/4} = 1:3$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: At constant pressure, which of the following represents the relation between volume V and temperature T of a gas? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: At constant pressure, which of the following represents the relation between volume $V$ and temperature $T$ of a gas? [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: According to Charles's Law, for a fixed mass of gas at constant pressure, the volume is directly proportional to its absolute temperature.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: A projectile is projected with velocity kve in vertically upward direction from the ground into the space (ve is the escape velocity and k < 1). If air resistance is considered to be negligible then the maximum height from the center of earth to which it can go will be (R = radius of earth)
question_latex: A projectile is projected with velocity $kv_{e}$ in vertically upward direction from the ground into the space ($v_{e}$ is the escape velocity and $k<1$). If air resistance is considered to be negligible then the maximum height from the center of earth to which it can go will be ($R = $ radius of earth)
solution:
Energy conservation: $\frac{1}{2}m(kv_{e})^{2} - \frac{GMm}{R} = -\frac{GMm}{h}$. 
 $\frac{1}{2} m k^{2} (\frac{2GM}{R}) - \frac{GMm}{R} = -\frac{GMm}{h}$ 
 $\frac{k^{2}-1}{R} = -\frac{1}{h} \Rightarrow h = \frac{R}{1-k^{2}}$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: For a gas, the ratio of specific heats is gamma = 1.4. The gas is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: For a gas, the ratio of specific heats is $\gamma = 1.4$. The gas is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: For a monoatomic gas $\gamma = 1.67$. For a diatomic gas (at moderate temperatures), $\gamma = 7/5 = 1.4$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Two projectiles of same mass have their maximum kinetic energies in the ratio 3:2. The ratio of maximum heights is also 3:2. The ratio of their horizontal ranges is [2025]
question_latex: Two projectiles of same mass have their maximum kinetic energies in the ratio $3:2$. The ratio of maximum heights is also $3:2$. The ratio of their horizontal ranges is [2025]
solution:
$K_{max} = \frac{1}{2}mu^{2} \Rightarrow u^{2} \propto K$. $H_{max} = \frac{u^{2} \sin^{2} \theta}{2g} \Rightarrow H \propto K \sin^{2} \theta$. 
 Since $K_{1}/K_{2} = 3/2$ and $H_{1}/H_{2} = 3/2$, we have $\sin^{2} \theta_{1} = \sin^{2} \theta_{2} \Rightarrow \theta_{1} = \theta_{2}$. 
 Range $R = \frac{u^{2} \sin 2\theta}{g} \propto u^{2} \propto K$. So $R_{1}/R_{2} = 3:2$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The rate of loss of heat from a body is 10 W when its temperature is 60°C and surrounding is 20°C. If temperature falls to 40°C, the rate of loss of heat will be [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: The rate of loss of heat from a body is $10~W$ when its temperature is $60^{\circ}C$ and surrounding is $20^{\circ}C$. If temperature falls to $40^{\circ}C$, the rate of loss of heat will be [MHT-CET 2020]
solution:
According to Newton's law of cooling, $\frac{dQ}{dt} \propto (T - T_{0})$. 
 $\frac{10}{R_{2}} = \frac{60 - 20}{40 - 20} = \frac{40}{20} = 2 \Rightarrow R_{2} = 5~W$.

solution: In the kinetic theory of gases derivation, the speed term $v$ (or $\bar{c}$) represents the root mean square speed of the gas molecules.

question_latex: The coefficient of absorption of a perfectly black body is [MHT-CET 2022]

question_latex: If the temperature of a body is doubled, the power radiated by it becomes [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: From Stefan's law, $P \propto T^{4}$. If $T$ is doubled, $P$ increases by $2^{4} = 16$ times.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The mean free path of a gas molecule is inversely proportional to [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: The mean free path of a gas molecule is inversely proportional to [MHT-CET 2021]
options: A. square of the diameter of the molecule
C. square root of the diameter
solution: The mean free path $\lambda = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}\pi d^{2}n}$. Thus $\lambda \propto \frac{1}{d^{2}}$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: A fighter plane enters inside the enemy territory, at time t=0 with velocity v0 = 250 ms^-1 and moves horizontally with constant acceleration a = 20 ms^-2. An enemy tank at the border, spot the plane and fire shots at an angle theta = 60° with the horizontal and with velocity u = 600 ms^-1. At what altitude H of the plane it can be hit by the shot?
question_latex: A fighter plane enters inside the enemy territory, at time $t=0$ with velocity $v_{0}=250~ms^{-1}$ and moves horizontally with constant acceleration $a=20ms^{-2}$ (see figure). An enemy tank at the border, spot the plane and fire shots at an angle $\theta=60^{\circ}$ with the horizontal and with velocity $u=600~ms^{-1}$. At what altitude $H$ of the plane it can be hit by the shot?
solution:
Horizontal collision condition: $x_{p} = x_{shot}$. 
 $250t + \frac{1}{2}(20)t^{2} = (600 \cos 60^{\circ}) t \Rightarrow 250t + 10t^{2} = 300t \Rightarrow 10t^{2} = 50t \Rightarrow t = 5$ s. 
 $H = (u \sin 60^{\circ})t - \frac{1}{2}gt^{2} = (600 \times 0.866) \times 5 - 5(25) = 2598 - 125 = 2473$ m.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: The ratio of molar specific heats Cp/Cv for a monoatomic gas is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: The ratio of molar specific heats $C_{p}/C_{v}$ for a monoatomic gas is [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: For a monoatomic gas, $C_{v} = \frac{3}{2}R$ and $C_{p} = \frac{5}{2}R$. Ratio $\gamma = 5/3 = 1.666 \approx 1.67$.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: A vehicle covers a distance 'x' with speed V1 and then same distance 'x' with speed V2 in the same direction. The average speed of the vehicle is [2025]
question_latex: A vehicle covers a distance '$x$' with speed $V_{1}$ and then same distance '$x$' with speed $V_{2}$ in the same direction. The average speed of the vehicle is [2025]
solution: Average speed $= \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Total time}} = \frac{2x}{x/V_{1} + x/V_{2}} = \frac{2x}{x(\frac{V_{1}+V_{2}}{V_{1}V_{2}})} = \frac{2V_{1}V_{2}}{V_{1}+V_{2}}$.

question_latex: The internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on its [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: As per Joule's Law for ideal gases, the internal energy is a function solely of the absolute temperature.

solution: $P = \frac{1}{3} \frac{N}{V} m v^{2} = \frac{2}{3} (\frac{E}{V})$. Pressure is $2/3$ times the average kinetic energy per unit volume.

chapter: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Radiation
question: Three bodies X, Y, Z of radii 2 cm, 3 cm and 6 cm radiate max energy at 9 micro-m, 4 micro-m and 5 micro-m. Power radiated Pz is maximum.
question_latex: Three bodies X, Y, Z of radii $2~cm, 3~cm$ and $6~cm$ radiate max energy at $9~\mu m, 4~\mu m$ and $5~\mu m$. Power radiated $P_{z}$ is maximum. [MHT-CET 2022]
solution:
$P \propto R^{2} T^{4}$. From Wien's law $T \propto 1/\lambda \Rightarrow P \propto R^{2}/\lambda^{4}$. 
 For X: $2^{2}/9^{4} = 4/6561 \approx 0.0006$ 
 For Y: $3^{2}/4^{4} = 9/256 \approx 0.035$ 
 For Z: $6^{2}/5^{4} = 36/625 \approx 0.057$. Thus $P_{z}$ is maximum.
